content.webTitle: SA Best vows to crack down on attack ads after 'dirty' election campaign

fields.headline: SA Best vows to crack down on attack ads after 'dirty' election campaign
fields.bodyText: One of Nick Xenophon’s few successful candidates in South Australia’s state election says he will use his position in the upper house to crack down on misleading political advertising after “the dirtiest campaign” he’s ever seen. The former Today Tonight journalist Frank Pangallo is, along with Xenophon’s former advisor Connie Bonaros, one of two SA-Best candidates likely to secure a seat in the legislative council out of election which saw the Liberals return to power under Steven Marshall. Pangallo told Guardian Australia attack campaigns from the pokies lobby, unions and the two major parties were a “tsunami of negativity” SA-Best couldn’t overcome in its bid to win lower house seats. “We knew it was going to be dirty, but not as dirty as it would be,” he said. “In my 46 years in the media and politics this is the dirtiest campaign I’ve ever seen waged.” He said the South Australian branch of the Australian Hotels Association “bought the election for the Liberal party” by spending millions of dollars on television advertising, campaign donations to both the Liberal and Labor candidates, letterboxing and ground-level campaigning. The campaign was particularly vigorous in Hartley, the seat which Xenophon himself lost to Liberal incumbent Vincent Tarzia. Pangallo also hit out at what he said were false claims made by the unions and Labor about Xenophon’s record of cutting education budgets and pensions. “They are outrageous lies, I’d like to change the Electoral Act,” he said. “These claims and advertisements need to be critically analysed, I’m pushing for truth in advertising judged by an independent authority. The South Australian Electoral Commission does not do enough.” When Xenophon appointed Pangallo as his media adviser in July last year, it seemed unlikely that nine months later the party leader would be out of office and the former journalist known for his confrontational style would be in power. Pangallo admitted the party’s probable failure to secure a single seat in the lower house fell short of even his earliest expectations when first enlisting with Xenophon’s startup political movement. Months before Xenophon quit federal politics and polls predicted SA-Best had a legitimate chance at forming government, Pangallo says he was “confident of at least five or six lower house seats”. “We went too big, too quickly,” he said. “With the benefit of hindsight, we shouldn’t have gone with 36 candidates, we didn’t have the resources and should have stayed under 20. The candidates didn’t have enough time to campaign in their electorates.” Observers have noted the campaign also appeared to lack the resources or structure to develop detailed policy positions on a range of platforms. SA-Best’s musical-themed advertising campaign also attracted plenty of scorn. Pangallo said Xenophon was “disappointed they bit off more than they could chew” but would remain an important part of the party decision-making process. Despite not being elected, Xenophon will serve as a “mentor” to Pangallo and Bonaros as they enter into a situation similar to the Nick Xenophon Team’s position in the federal Senate. Although final numbers are to be determined, the Liberal government elected in South Australia is certain to need support of crossbenchers in the upper house, meaning SA-Best will enjoy significant negotiating power. “Nick certainly has a strong role to continue to play in SA-Best and in politics,” Pangallo said. “He is the leader, but we consult with each other and are all about consensus.” Xenophon himself has ruled out taking the spots of one of SA-Best’s council members in a casual vacancy, and at a press conference on Sunday on the steps of South Australia’s Parliament House, he indicated he wanted to take a step back from politics for a period. Xenophon also brought up a text message he said he received from someone in the gaming lobby threatening to “kill you all off”. Pangallo had his own warning for the pokies industry. “They wanted to kill us off, but they haven’t,” he said. “They may have won battle, but they haven’t won the war. I haven’t gone away, and neither has Nick.”
